analyzed: a vācyam api guroḥ nyagbhāvam avādīt punar guru kulam prati preṣaṇa bhayāt
translated: He spoke again of the disrespect towards the teacher, which should not have been spoken, out of fear of being sent back to the teacher's house.

original: ato bhagavāṃstveva me mahyaṃ tadvastu yena sarvajñatvaṃ jñātena me syāttadbravītu kathayatvityuktaḥ pitovāca tathāstu saumyeti // //🔽iti cchāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭhādhyāyasya prathamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
analyzed: atas bhagavān tu eva me mahyam tat vastu yena sarvajña tvam jñātena me syāt tat bravītu kathayatu iti uktaḥ pitā uvāca tathā astu saumya iti  iti chāndogya upaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya prathamaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Therefore, O Lord, tell me that matter by knowing which I shall become omniscient. Speak it. Thus addressed, the father said, So be it, my dear.

original: START ChUp / /🔽sad eva somyedam agra āsīd ekam evādvitīyam /
analyzed: start chup  sat eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam
translated: Thus ends the First Section in the Sixth Chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.🔽In the beginning, O Somya, this was Being only, one only, without a second.

original: tad dhaika āhur asad evedam agra āsīd ekam evādvitīyam /
analyzed: tat ha eke āhuḥ asat eva idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam
translated: They say that in the beginning this was non-Being only, one only, without a second.

analyzed: tasmāt asataḥ sat jāyata
translated: From that non-Being Being was produced.

original: sadeva sadityastitāmātraṃ vastu sūkṣmaṃ nirviśeṣaṃ sarvagatamekaṃ nirañjanaṃ niravayavaṃ vijñānaṃ yadavagamyate sarvavedāntebhyaḥ
analyzed: sat eva sat iti astitā mātram vastu sūkṣmam nirviśeṣam sarva gatam ekam nirañjanam niravayavam vijñānam yat avagamyate sarva vedāntebhyaḥ
translated: The Being is the subtle, undifferentiated, all-pervading, one, unstained, partless knowledge which is understood from all the Vedāntas.

analyzed: eva śabdaḥ vadhāraṇa arthaḥ
translated: The word eva (only) is for the purpose of restriction.

analyzed: kim tat avadhriyate iti āha
translated: What was that? He says:

analyzed: idam jagat nāma rūpa kriyāvat vikṛtam upalabhyate yat tat sat eva āsīt iti āsīt śabdena sambadhyate
translated: This world, which is perceived as diversified with names and forms and actions, was indeed Being. The word was is connected.

analyzed: kadā sat eva idam āsīt iti ucte
translated: When was this world indeed Being? It is said:

analyzed: agre jagataḥ prāk utpatteḥ
translated: Before, prior to the origination of the world.

analyzed: kim na idānīm idam yat yena agre āsīt iti viśeṣyate
translated: Was it not so even now, if it is specified that it was so before?

analyzed: na katham tarhi viśeṣaṇam
translated: No. Then how is it qualified?

original: idānīmapīdaṃ sadeva kintu nāmarūpaviśeṣaṇavadidaṃśabdabuddhiviṣayaṃ cetīdaṃ ca bhavati /
analyzed: idānīm api idam sat eva kintu nāma rūpa viśeṣaṇavat idam śabda buddhi viṣayam ca iti idam ca bhavati
translated: Even now this is indeed Being, but it has the distinction of names and forms, and is the object of the word this and the intellect. It becomes this.

analyzed: prāk utpatteḥ tu agre kevala sat śabda buddhi mātra gamyam eva iti sat eva idam agre āsīt iti avadhāryate
translated: But before origination, before, it is known only by the word Being and the intellect alone. Thus it is determined that this world was indeed Being before.

original: na hi prāgutpatternāmavadrūpavadvedamiti grahītuṃ śakyaṃ vastu suṣuptakāla iva /
analyzed: na hi prāk utpatteḥ nāmavat rūpavat vā idam iti grahītum śakyam vastu suṣupta kāle iva
translated: For before origination, the entity cannot be grasped as having a name or form, like at the time of deep sleep.

original: yathā suṣuptādutthitaḥ sattvamātramavagacchati suṣupte sanmātrameva kevalaṃ vastviti tathā prāgutpatterityabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: yathā suṣuptāt utthitaḥ sattva mātram avagacchati suṣupte sat mātram eva kevalam vastu iti tathā prāk utpatteḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The idea is that just as one, on rising from deep sleep, understands mere existence, that in deep sleep the entity is mere Being alone, so also before origination.

original: yathedamucyate loke pūrvāhne ghaṭādi sisṛkṣuṇā kulālena mṛtpiṇḍaṃ prasāritamupalabhya
analyzed: yathā idam ucyate loke pūrvāhne ghaṭa ādi sisṛkṣuṇā kulālena mṛd piṇḍam prasāritam upalabhya
translated: As it is said in the world: a potter, desiring to create a pot etc. in the morning, finds the lump of clay spread out,

original: grāmāntaraṃ gatvā pratyāgato 'parāhne tatraiva ghaṭaśarāvādyanekabhedabhinnaṃ kāryamupalabhya
analyzed: grāma antaram gatvā pratyāgataḥ parāhne tatra eva ghaṭa śarāva ādi aneka bheda bhinnam kāryam upalabhya
translated: goes to another village and returns in the afternoon, and there, in the same place, finds the effect divided into many kinds such as pots, bowls etc.,

original: mṛdevedaṃ ghaṭaśarāvādi kevalaṃ pūrvāhne āsīditi tathehāpyucyate sadevedamagra āsīditi /
analyzed: mṛdā iva idam ghaṭa śarāva ādi kevalam pūrvāhne āsīt iti tathā iha api ucyate sat eva idam agre āsīt iti
translated: and says this pot, bowl etc. was only clay in the morning. In the same way, it is said here this existent was only in the beginning.

analyzed: ekam eva iti
translated: One only.

analyzed: sva kārya patitam anyat na asti iti ekam eva iti ucyate
translated: It is said to be one only because there is nothing else fallen into its own effect.

analyzed: advitīyam iti
translated: Without a second.

analyzed: mṛd vyatirekeṇa mṛdaḥ yathā anyat ghaṭa ādi ākāreṇa pariṇamayitṛ kulāla ādi nimitta kāraṇam dṛṣṭam
translated: Just as in the case of clay, a cause such as a potter is seen that transforms it into other forms such as pots etc. apart from the clay,

original: tathā sadvyatirekeṇa sataḥ sahakārikāraṇaṃ dvitīyaṃ vastvantaraṃ prāptaṃ pratiṣidhyate 'dvitīyamiti /
analyzed: tathā sat vyatirekeṇa sataḥ sahakāri kāraṇam dvitīyam vastu antaram prāptam pratiṣidhyate dvitīyam iti
translated: in the same way, apart from the existent, a second thing, a cooperating cause, is denied in the case of the existent, saying without a second.

analyzed: na asya dvitīyam vastu antaram vidyate iti advitīyam
translated: It is without a second because there is no other thing as a second.

analyzed: nanu veśeṣika pakṣe sat sāmānādhikaramyam sarvasya upapadyate
translated: But even in the Vaiśeṣika view, the identity of locus of the existent is possible for everything,

analyzed: dravya guṇa ādiṣu sat śabda buddhi anuvṛtteḥ
translated: because the word existent and the cognition continue in substances, qualities etc.

analyzed: sat dravyam sat guṇaḥ sat karma ityādi darśanāt
translated: Because we find such expressions as 'a real substance', 'a real quality', 'a real action', and so on.

original: satyamevaṃ syādidānīṃ prāgutpattestu naivedaṃ kāryaṃ sadevā'sīdityabhyupagamyate vaiśeṣikaiḥ prāgutpatteḥ kāryasyāsattvābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: satyam evam syāt idānīm prāk utpatteḥ tu na eva idam kāryam sat eva āsīt iti abhyupagamyate vaiśeṣikaiḥ prāk utpatteḥ kāryasya asattva abhyupagamāt
translated: This would be true, but the Vaiśeṣikas accept that before creation, this effect was not real, because they accept that before creation, the effect did not exist.

analyzed: na ca ekam eva sat advitīyam prak utpatteḥ icchanti
translated: And they do not want the one real thing to be without a second before creation.

analyzed: tasmāt vaiśeṣika parikalpitāt sataḥ nyat kāraṇam idam sat ucyate mṛd ādi dṛṣṭāntebhyaḥ
translated: Therefore, this cause is said to be real, different from the real imagined by the Vaiśeṣikas, due to the examples of clay and so on.

original: tattatra haitasminprāgutpattervastunirūpaṇa eke vaināśikā āhurvastu nirūpayanto 'satsadabhāvamātraṃ prāgutpatteridaṃ jagadekamevāgre 'dvitīyamāsīditi
analyzed: tat tatra ha etasmin prāgutpatteḥ vastu nirūpaṇe eke vaināśikāḥ āhuḥ vastu sat sat abhāva mātram prāk utpatteḥ idam jagat ekam eva agre dvitīyam āsīt iti
translated: There, in this description of the entity before creation, some nihilists, describing the entity, say that before creation, this world was non-existent, just the absence of existence, and was originally one without a second.

analyzed: sat abhāva mātram hi prāk utpatteḥ tattvam kalpayanti bauddhāḥ
translated: For the Buddhists imagine that before creation, its reality is just the absence of existence.

analyzed: na tu sat pratidvandvi vastu antaram icchanti
translated: But they do not want a real entity that is the opposite of existence.

original: yathā saccāsaditi gṛhyamāmaṃ yathābhūtaṃ tadviparītaṃ tattvaṃ bhavatīti naiyāyikāḥ /
analyzed: yathā sat ca asat iti gṛhyamāmam yathābhūtam tad viparītam tattvam bhavati iti naiyāyikāḥ
translated: As the Naiyāyikas say, when something is grasped as both existent and non-existent, that reality is contrary to how it actually is.

original: nanu sadabhāvamātraṃ prāgutpatteścedabhipretaṃ vaināśikaiḥ kathaṃ prāgutpatteridamāsīdasadekamevādvitīyaṃ ceti kālasambandhaḥ saṃkhyāsambandho
analyzed: nanu sat abhāva mātram prāk utpatteḥ ced abhipretam vaināśikaiḥ katham prāk utpatteḥ idam āsīt asat ekam eva advitīyam ca iti kāla sambandhaḥ
translated: If the annihilationists intend to assert the mere non-existence of an existent prior to origination, how can they speak of a relation to time, a relation to number, and non-duality, saying prior to origination this was non-existent, one without a second?

analyzed: dvitīya tvam ca ucyate taiḥ
translated: How can they speak of non-duality?

analyzed: bāḍham na yuktam teṣām bhāva abhāva mātram abhyupagacchatām
translated: Indeed, it is not proper for them who accept mere existence and non-existence.

analyzed: asattava mātra abhyupagamaḥ pi ayuktaḥ eva abhyupagantuḥ anabhyupagama anupapatteḥ
translated: Accepting mere non-existence is also improper, because it is impossible for the accepter not to accept.

analyzed: idānīm abhyupagantā abhyupagamyate na prāk utpatteḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the accepter is accepted now, not prior to origination, that is not so.

original: prāgutpatteḥ sadabhāvasya pramāṇābhāvāt prāgutpatterasadevetikalpanānupapattiḥ /🔽nanu kathaṃ vastvākṛteḥ śabdārthatve 'sadekamevādvitīyamitipadārthavākyārthopapatt iḥ /
analyzed: prāk utpatteḥ sat abhāvasya pramāṇa abhāvāt prāk utpatteḥ asat eva iti kalpanā anupapattiḥ  nanu katham vastu ākṛteḥ śabda artha tve sat ekam eva advitīyam iti padārtha vākyārtha upapatt iḥ
translated: Because there is no evidence for the non-existence of an existent prior to origination, it is impossible to imagine that it was non-existent prior to origination.🔽If it is argued that in the case of the meaning of a word being the form of an existent, how can the meaning of the sentence non-existent, one without a second be proper?

analyzed: tad anupapattau ca idam vākyam apramāṇam prasajyeta iti ca iti
translated: And if that is not proper, this sentence would be invalid,

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ  sat grahaṇa nivṛtti paratvāt vākyasya
translated: that is not a fault.🔽Because the sentence is intended to negate the grasping of existence.

analyzed: sat iti ayam tāvat śabdaḥ sat ākṛti vācakaḥ
translated: This word sat (existent) is indeed a denoter of the form of an existent.

analyzed: ekam eva advitīyam iti etau ca sat śabdena samāna adhikaraṇau
translated: The two statements, 'One only, without a second', and 'This was in the beginning', have the same subject as the word 'Sat'.

original: tathedamāsīditi ca /🔽tatra nañ sadvākye prayuktaḥ sadvākyamevāvalambya sadvākyārthaviṣayāṃ buddhiṃ sadekamevādvitīyamidamāsīdityevaṃlakṣaṇāṃ
analyzed: tathā idam āsīt iti ca  tatra sat vākye prayuktaḥ sat vākyam eva avalambya sat vākya artha viṣayām buddhim sat ekam eva advitīyam idam āsīt iti evaṃlakṣaṇām
translated: Similarly, 'This was in the beginning'.🔽There, the negative particle used in the sentence 'Sat' relies on the sentence 'Sat' itself and turns the mind towards the meaning of the sentence 'Sat', which has the characteristic of 'Sat', 'One only', 'without a second', 'This was in the beginning'.

analyzed: tatas sat vākya arthān nivartayati aśva ārūḍhaḥ śvam tad abhimukha viṣayān nivartayati tadvat
translated: Then, like a horseman relying on a horse turns the horse away from its object towards himself, it turns away from the meaning of the sentence 'Sat'.

analyzed: na tu punar sat abhāvam eva abhidhatteḥ
translated: But it does not again express the mere non-existence of 'Sat'.

analyzed: atas puruṣasya viparīta grahaṇa nivṛtti artha param idam asat eva ityādi vākyam prayujyate
translated: Therefore, this sentence 'Asat' etc. is used with the purpose of removing the contrary grasping of the person.

original: darśayitvā hi viparītagrahaṇaṃ tato nivartayituṃ śakyata ityarthavattvādasadādivākyasya śrautatvaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ ca siddhamityadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: darśayitvā hi viparīta grahaṇam tatas nivartayitum śakyate iti arthavat tvāt asat ādi vākyasya śrauta tvam prāmāṇyam ca siddham iti adoṣaḥ
translated: For, having shown the contrary grasping, it can be removed. Thus, the meaningfulness and the authoritative nature of the sentence 'Asat' etc. are established. Therefore, there is no fault.

analyzed: tasmāt asataḥ sarva abhāva rūpāt sat vidyamānam ajāyata samutpannam
translated: Therefore, from 'Asat', which is of the form of the non-existence of all, 'Sat', which exists, was born, was produced.

analyzed: aṭ abhāvaḥ chāndasaḥ
translated: The absence of 'a' is Vedic.

analyzed: start chup
translated: Chandogya Upanishad

original: kutas tu khalu somyaivaṃ syād iti hovāca /
analyzed: kutas tu khalu somya evam syāt iti ha uvāca
translated: But, my dear, how could this be? he said.

analyzed: katham asataḥ sat jāyeta
translated: How can the existent be born from the non-existent?

original: sat tv eva somyedam agra āsīd ekam evādvitīyam // / / //🔽tadetadviparītagrahaṇaṃ mahāvaināśikapakṣaṃ darśayitvā pratiṣedhatikutastu
analyzed: sat tu eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam  tat etat viparīta grahaṇam mahā vaināśika pakṣam darśayitvā pratiṣedhati kutas tu
translated: But, my dear, this was indeed existent in the beginning, one only, without a second.

original: pramāṇātkhalu he somyaivaṃ syādasataḥ sajjāyatetyevaṃ kuto bhavenna kutaścitpramāṇādevaṃ🔽sambhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: pramāṇāt khalu he somya evam syāt asataḥ sat jāyata iti evam kutas bhavet na kutaścid pramāṇāt evam  sambhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Having thus shown the view of the great nihilists, which is the opposite of this, he refutes it. From what evidence, indeed, my dear, could this be so, that the existent is born from the non-existent? How could this be so? From no evidence whatsoever. This is the meaning.

original: yadapi bījopamarde 'ṅkuro jāyamāno dṛṣṭo 'bhāvadeveti tadapyabhyupagamaviruddhaṃ teṣām /
analyzed: yat api bīja upamarde ṅkuraḥ jāyamānaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ bhāva deva iti tat api abhyupagama viruddham teṣām
translated: Even what is seen, that the sprout is born when the seed is destroyed, that is also contrary to their acceptance.

original: katham /🔽ye tāvadbījāvayavā bījasaṃsthānaviśiṣṭāste 'ṅkure 'pyanuvartanta eva na teṣāmupamarde 'ṅkurajanmani /
analyzed: katham  ye tāvat bīja avayavāḥ bīja saṃsthāna viśiṣṭāḥ te ṅkure pi anuvartante eva na teṣām upamarde ṅkura janmani
translated: How?🔽Those parts of the seed that are distinguished by the shape of the seed continue in the sprout as well. There is no destruction of them in the birth of the sprout.

original: yatpunarbījākārasaṃsthānaṃ tadbījāvayavavyatirekeṇa vastubhūtaṃ na vaināśikairabhyupagamyate yadaṅkurajanmanyupamṛdyeta /
analyzed: yat punar bīja ākāra saṃsthānam tat bīja avayava vyatirekeṇa vastu bhūtam na vaināśikaiḥ abhyupagamyate yat aṅkura janmani upamṛdyeta
translated: But that which is the shape of the seed, which is a real entity separate from the parts of the seed, is not accepted by the nihilists as something that could be destroyed in the birth of the sprout.

original: atha tadastyavayavavyatiriktaṃ vastubhūtaṃ tathā ca satyabhyupagamavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: atha tat asti avayava vyatiriktam vastu bhūtam tathā ca satī abhyupagama virodhaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, it exists as a real entity separate from the parts, then there is a contradiction with their acceptance.

analyzed: atha saṃvṛtya abhyupagatam bīja saṃsthāna rūpam upamṛdyate iti ced
translated: If it is said that the form of the seed's shape accepted conventionally is destroyed,

analyzed: kā iyam saṃvṛtiḥ nāma kim asau abhāvaḥ uta
translated: what is this so-called convention? Is it non-existence or existence?
If it is non-existence, there is no example.

analyzed: atha bhāvaḥ tathā api na abhāvāt aṅkura utpattiḥ bīja avayavebhyaḥ hi aṅkura utpattiḥ
translated: Even if it is existence, still the sprout does not arise from non-existence, because the sprout arises from the parts of the seed.

analyzed: avayavāḥ api upamṛdyante iti ced na
translated: If it is said that the parts are also destroyed, no.

analyzed: tad avayaveṣu tulya tvāt
translated: Because it is the same with respect to their parts.

original: yathā vaināśikānāṃ bījasaṃsthānarūpo 'vayavī nāsti tathāvayavā apīti teṣāmapyupamardānupapattiḥ /🔽bījāvayavānāmapi sūkṣmāvayavāstadavayavānāmapyanye sūkṣmatarāvayavā ityevaṃ prasaṅgasyānivṛtteḥ sarvatropamardānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: yathā vaināśikānām bīja saṃsthāna rūpaḥ vayavī na asti tathā avayavāḥ api iti teṣām api upamarda anupapattiḥ  bīja avayavānām api sūkṣma avayavāḥ tad avayavānām api anye sūkṣmatara avayavāḥ iti evam prasaṅgasya anivṛtteḥ sarvatra upamarda anupapattiḥ
translated: Just as for the annihilationists there is no whole in the form of the seed's shape, so too the parts do not exist. Therefore for them also destruction is not possible.

original: sadbuddhyanuvṛtteḥ sattvānivṛttiśceti sadvādināṃ sata eva sadutpattiḥ setsyati /
analyzed: sat buddhi anuvṛtteḥ sattva anivṛttiḥ ca iti sat vādinām sataḥ eva sat utpattiḥ setsyati
translated: Since the continuation of the designation of existence is due to the continuation of the cognition of existence, the non-cessation of existence is established. Thus for the proponents of existence, the arising of existence from existence will be established.

analyzed: na tu asat vādinām dṛṣṭāntaḥ asti asataḥ sat utpatteḥ
translated: But for the proponents of non-existence, there is no example of the arising of existence from non-existence.

analyzed: mṛd piṇḍāt ghaṭa utpattiḥ dṛśyate sat vādinām tad bhāve bhāvāt tad abhāve ca abhāvāt
translated: For the proponents of existence, the arising of the pot from the lump of clay is seen, because it exists when that exists and does not exist when that does not exist.

original: yadyabhāvādeva ghaṭa utpadyeta ghaṭārthinā mṛtpiṇḍo nopādīyeta /
analyzed: yadi abhāvāt eva ghaṭaḥ utpadyeta ghaṭa arthinā mṛd piṇḍaḥ na upādīyeta
translated: If a pot were produced from non-existence, one desiring a pot would not take up a lump of clay.

analyzed: abhāva śabda buddhi anuvṛttiḥ ca ghaṭa ādau prasajyeta
translated: And the application of the words and concepts of non-existence would follow in the case of a pot, etc.

analyzed: na tu etat asti atas na asataḥ sat utpattiḥ
translated: But this is not so. Therefore, an existent is not produced from a non-existent.

original: yadapyāhurmṛdbuddhirghaṭabuddhernimittamiti mṛdbuddhirghaṭabuddheḥ kāraṇamucyate🔽na tu paramārthata eva mṛdghaṭo vāstīti tadapi mṛdbuddhirvidyamānā vidyamānāyā eva
analyzed: yat api āhuḥ mṛd buddhiḥ ghaṭa buddheḥ nimittam iti mṛd buddhiḥ ghaṭa buddheḥ kāraṇam ucyate  na tu paramārthataḥ eva mṛd ghaṭaḥ vā asti iti tat api mṛd buddhiḥ vidyamānā vidyamānāyāḥ eva
translated: As for what they say - The concept of clay is the cause of the concept of pot - the concept of clay is said to be the cause of the concept of pot,

analyzed: ghaṭa buddheḥ kāraṇam iti na asataḥ sat utpattiḥ
translated: but it is not that in the highest sense, clay and pot really exist. That also is the concept of clay, which exists, being the cause of the concept of pot, which exists. Thus, an existent is not produced from a non-existent.

analyzed: mṛd ghaṭa buddhyoḥ nimitta naimittika tayā ānantarya mātram na tu kārya kāraṇatvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the concept of clay and the concept of pot are merely sequential due to being cause and effect, but not actually cause and effect, that is not so.

analyzed: buddhīnām nairantarye gamyamāne vaināśikānām bahis dṛṣṭānta abhāvāt
translated: When the sequence of concepts is understood, the Vainaśikas have no external examples.

original: ataḥ kutastu khalu somyaivaṃ syāditi hovāca kathaṃ kena prakāreṇāsataḥ sajjāyeteti /
analyzed: atas kutas tu khalu somya evam syāt iti ha uvāca katham kena prakāreṇa asataḥ sat jāyeta iti
translated: Therefore, From what, verily, my dear, could this be? he said. How, in what manner, could the existent be produced from the non-existent?

analyzed: asataḥ sat utpattau na kaścid api dṛṣṭānta prakāraḥ sti iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no example whatsoever of the production of an existent from a non-existent.

analyzed: evam asat vādi pakṣam unmadhya upasaṃharati sattvā iva somya idam agre āsīt iti sva pakṣa siddhim
translated: Thus, having refuted the doctrine of the non-existence of the effect in the cause, he concludes his own doctrine, Only this existed in the beginning, O dear one, by establishing its validity.

original: nanu sadvādino 'pi sataḥ sadutpadyata iti naiva dṛṣṭānto 'sti /
analyzed: nanu sat vādinaḥ sataḥ sat utpadyate iti na eva dṛṣṭāntaḥ sti
translated: But even for the proponents of existence, there is no example of the existent being produced from the existent,

analyzed: ghaṭāt ghaṭa antara utpatti adarśanāt
translated: because the production of another pot from a pot is not seen.

original: satyamevaṃ na sataḥ sadantaramutpadyate kiṃ tarhi sadeva saṃsthānāntareṇāvatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: satyam evam na sataḥ sat antaram utpadyate kim tarhi sat eva saṃsthāna antareṇa avatiṣṭhate
translated: It is true that another existent is not produced from the existent. But rather, the existent itself remains in a different form.

analyzed: yathā sarpaḥ kuṇḍalī bhavati
translated: Just as a snake becomes coiled,

analyzed: yathā ca mṛd cūrṇa piṇḍa ghaṭa kapāla ādi prabhedaiḥ
translated: and just as clay remains as the object of words and concepts such as powder, lump, pot, shard, etc.

analyzed: yadi evam sat eva sarva prakāra avastham prāk utpatteḥ idam āsīt iti
translated: If that is so, how can it be said that this existed before creation, when the existent remains in all forms?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: nanu na śrutaṃ tvayā sadevetyava dhāraṇamidaṃśabdavācyasya kāryasya /
analyzed: nanu na śrutam tvayā dhāraṇam idam śabda vācyasya kāryasya
translated: Have you not heard that the existent alone is the substratum of this word?

analyzed: prāptam tarhi prāk utpatteḥ asat eva āsīt na idam śabda vācyam idānīm idam jātam iti  na
translated: Then it follows that before creation, it was indeed non-existent, not the object of the word this, and now this is born. No.

analyzed: sataḥ eva idam śabda buddhi viṣaya tayā avasthānāt yathā mṛdā iva piṇḍa ghaṭa ādi śabda buddhi viṣaya tvena avatiṣṭhate tadvat
translated: Because the existent alone remains as the object of the word and cognition of this, just as clay alone remains as the object of words and cognitions such as lump, pot, etc.

original: nanu yathā mṛdvastvevaṃ piṇḍaghaṭādyapi tadvatsadbuddheranyabuddhiviṣayatvātkāryasya sato 'nyadvastvantaraṃ syātkāryajātaṃ yathāśvādgauḥ /🔽piṇḍaghaṭādīnāmitaretaravyabhicāre 'pi mṛttvāvyabhicārāt /
analyzed: nanu yathā mṛd vastu evam piṇḍa ghaṭa ādi api tadvat sat buddheḥ anya buddhi viṣaya tvāt kāryasya sataḥ nyat vastu antaram syāt kārya jātam yathā aśvāt gauḥ  piṇḍa ghaṭa ādīnām itaretara vyabhicāre pi mṛd tva avyabhicārāt
translated: But just as a pot is a substance, so also a lump, a pot, etc. are like that. Because the effect is the object of a different cognition than the cognition of existence, the class of effects would be a different substance, like a cow from a horse.🔽Even though a lump and a pot, etc. differ from each other, they do not differ from being clay.

original: yadyapi ghaṭaḥ piṇḍaṃ vyabhicarati piṇḍaśca ghaṭaṃ tathāpi mṛttavaṃ na vyabhicaratastasmānmṛnmātraṃ piṇḍaghaṭau /
analyzed: yadi api ghaṭaḥ piṇḍam vyabhicarati piṇḍaḥ ca ghaṭam tathā api mṛd tavam na vyabhicarataḥ tasmāt mṛd mātram piṇḍa ghaṭau
translated: Even though a pot differs from a lump and a lump differs from a pot, they do not differ from being clay. Therefore, a lump and a pot are mere clay.

analyzed: vyabhicarati tu aśvam gauḥ aśvaḥ vā gām
translated: But a horse differs from a cow and a cow from a horse.

analyzed: tasmāt mṛd ādi saṃsthāna mātram ghaṭa ādayaḥ
translated: Therefore, pots, etc. are merely the arrangement of clay, etc.

analyzed: evam sat saṃsthāna mātram idam sarvam iti yuktam prāk utpatteḥ  sadā eva iti
translated: Thus, it is proper to say that this entire universe is merely the arrangement of existence prior to creation.

original: vācārambhaṇamātratvādvikārasaṃsthānamātrasya /🔽nanu niravayavaṃ satniṣkalaṃ niṣkriyaṃ śāntaṃ niravadyaṃ nirañjanaṃ divyo hyamūrtaḥ
analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇa mātra tvāt vikāra saṃsthāna mātrasya  nanu niravayavam sat niṣkalam niṣkriyam śāntam niravadyam nirañjanam divyaḥ hi amūrtaḥ
translated: Only existence means that the universe is merely the arrangement of modifications, because it is merely verbal designation.🔽But how can the arrangement of modifications be logically possible for existence, which is partless, without parts, without action, tranquil, faultless, and free from passion, since it is taught in the scriptures that the divine, formless, unborn person is without and within?

original: puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaityādiśrutibhyo niravayavasya sataḥ kathaṃ vikārasaṃsthānamupapadyate /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ sa bāhya abhyantaraḥ hi aja etyādi śrutibhyaḥ niravayavasya sataḥ katham vikāra saṃsthānam upapadyate
translated: How can the arrangement of modifications be logically possible for partless existence?

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: rajju ādi avayavebhyaḥ sarpa ādi saṃsthāna vat buddhi pārikalpitebhyaḥ sat avayavebyaḥ vikāra saṃsthāna upapatteḥ
translated: Just as the shape of a snake, etc. is imagined by the intellect from the parts of a rope, etc., so the shape of modification is possible from the real parts.

original: vācā'rambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttiketyeva satyamevaṃ sadeva satyamiti śruteḥ /
analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam mṛttikā iti eva satyam evam sat eva satyam iti śruteḥ
translated: Modification is verbal designation, clay is the only reality, thus indeed is reality, thus indeed is the only truth, according to the Upanishad.

analyzed: ekam eva advitīyam paramārthataḥ idam buddhi kāle pi
translated: One without a second is the ultimate reality, even at the time of the cognition of this.

analyzed: start chup
translated: Chandogya Upanishad

analyzed: tat aikṣata
translated: It desired.

analyzed: bahu syām prajāyeya iti  tat tejaḥ sṛjata
translated: 'May I become many. May I procreate.'🔽It created fire.

analyzed: tat tejaḥ aikṣata
translated: That fire desired.

analyzed: bahu syām prajāyeya iti
translated: 'May I become many. May I procreate.'

analyzed: tat apaḥ sṛjata
translated: It created water.

original: tasmād yatra kva ca śocati svedate vā puruṣas tejasa eva tad adhy āpo jāyante // / / //
analyzed: tasmāt yatra kva ca śocati svedate vā puruṣaḥ tejasaḥ eva tat adhi āpaḥ jāyante
translated: Therefore, wherever a person grieves or sweats, water is born from fire alone.

analyzed: tat sat aikṣata īkṣām darśanam kṛta vat
translated: It desired, it saw.

analyzed: atas ca na pradhānam sāṃkhya parikalpitam jagat kāraṇam
translated: And therefore, the prakriti postulated by the Sankhyas is not the cause of the world.

analyzed: pradhānasya acetana tva abhyupadamāt
translated: Because the prakriti is accepted to be non-sentient.

analyzed: idam tu sat cetanam īkṣitṛ tvāt
translated: But this is sentient, because it is the seer.

original: tatkathamaikṣatetyāhabahu prabhūtaṃ syāṃ bhaveyaṃ prajāyeta prakarṣeṇotpadyeya /
analyzed: tat katham aikṣata iti āha bahu prabhūtam syām bhaveyam prajāyeta prakarṣeṇa utpadyeya
translated: How did it desire? It said, 'May I become many, abundant, may I procreate, may I be born with excellence.'

original: yathā mṛdghaṭādyākareṇa yathā vā rajjavādi sarpādyākāreṇa buddhiparikalpitena /
analyzed: yathā mṛd ghaṭa ādi ākareṇa yathā vā rajjavādi sarpa ādi ākāreṇa buddhi parikalpitena
translated: Just as a clay pot is imagined by the intellect to have the form of a pot, or just as a rope, etc. is imagined by the intellect to have the form of a snake, etc.

original: asadeva tarhi sarvaṃ yadgṛhyate rajjuriva sarpādyākāreṇa buddhiparikalpitena /
analyzed: asat eva tarhi sarvam yat gṛhyate rajjuḥ iva sarpa ādi ākāreṇa buddhi parikalpitena
translated: Then everything that is grasped is unreal, like a rope imagined by the intellect to have the form of a snake, etc.

original: asadeva tarhi sarvaṃ yadgṛhyate rajjuriva sarpādyākareṇa / na /
analyzed: asat eva tarhi sarvam yat gṛhyate rajjuḥ iva sarpa ādi ākareṇa na
translated: No, everything is not unreal, like a rope imagined to have the form of a snake, etc.

analyzed: sataḥ eva dvaita bhedena anyathā gṛhyamāṇa tvāt na asattvam kasyacid kvacid iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say that nothing is non-existent anywhere, because it is grasped differently as dualistic and separate.

original: yathā sato 'nyadvastvantaraṃ parikalpya punastasyaiva prāgutpatteḥ pradhvaṃsāccordhvamasattvaṃ
analyzed: yathā sataḥ nyat vastu antaram parikalpya punar tasya eva prāc utpatteḥ pradhvaṃsāt ca ūrdhvam asattvam
translated: Just as logicians imagine a different entity than what exists and say that it is non-existent before arising and after destruction,

original: bruvate tārkikā na tathāsmābhiḥ kadācitkvacidipi sato 'nyadabhidhānamabhidheyaṃ vā🔽vastu parikalpyate /
analyzed: bruvate tārkikāḥ na tathā asmābhiḥ kadācid kvacid ipi sataḥ ni ad abhidhānam abhidheyam vā  vastu parikalpyate
translated: we never imagine anywhere any different expression or object than what exists.

analyzed: sat eva tu sarvam abhidhānam abhidhīyate ca yat anya buddhyā
translated: But everything is expressed and expressed as different from another cognition.

original: tathā rajjureva sarpabuddhyā sarpa ityabhidhīyate yathā vā piṇḍaghaṭādi mṛdo 'nyabuddhyā piṇḍaghaṭādiśabdenābhidhīyate loke /
analyzed: tathā rajjuḥ eva sarpa buddhyā sarpaḥ iti abhidhīyate yathā vā piṇḍa ghaṭa ādi mṛdaḥ nya buddhyā piṇḍa ghaṭa ādi śabdena abhidhīyate loke
translated: Just as a rope is expressed as a snake by the cognition of a snake, or just as a lump, pot, etc. is expressed by the word lump, pot, etc. in the world by the cognition of something different from clay.

original: rajjuvivekadarśināṃ tu sarpābhidhānabuddhī nivartete yathā ca mṛdvivekadarśināṃ ghaṭādiśabdabuddhī tadvatsadvivekadarśināmanyavikāraśabdabuddhī
analyzed: rajju viveka darśinām tu sarpa abhidhāna buddhī nivartete yathā ca mṛd viveka darśinām ghaṭa ādi śabda buddhī tadvat sat viveka darśinām anya vikāra śabda buddhī
translated: But for those who perceive the distinction of the rope, the notions of snake are reversed, and similarly for those who perceive the distinction of clay, the notions of pot and so on. In the same way, for those who perceive the distinction of the real, the notions of other modifications and words are reversed.

analyzed: nivartete
translated: They cease.

analyzed: yatas vācaḥ nivartante
translated: From which words turn back,

analyzed: a prāpya manasā saha iti anirukte nilayana etyādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: along with the mind, unable to reach it, as stated in the scriptures such as It is not spoken, it is not a resting place.

analyzed: evam īkṣitvā tat tejaḥ sṛjata tejaḥ sṛṣṭa vat
translated: Having thus seen, He created that fire. Having created fire,

original: nanu tasmādvā etasmādātmana ākāśaḥ saṃbhūta iti śrutyantara ākāśādvāyustatastṛtīyaṃ tejaḥ śrutamiha tu katha prāthamyena tasmādeva tejaḥ sṛjyate
analyzed: nanu tasmāt vai etasmāt ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ iti śruti antare ākāśāt vāyuḥ tatas tṛtīyam tejaḥ śrutam iha tu prāthamyena tasmāt eva tejaḥ sṛjyate  /
translated: But in another scripture it is stated that From that Self, space was produced, and from space, air, and from that, the third, fire is heard. But here, how is it that from that very fire, creation is made first,

analyzed: tatas eva ca ākāśam iti viruddham
translated: and from that very space? This is contradictory.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: ākāśa vāyu sarga anantaram tat sat tejaḥ sṛjata iti kalpanā upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible to imagine that after the creation of space and air, He created that fire.

original: atha vāvivakṣita iha sṛṣṭikramaḥ satkāryamidaṃ sarvamataḥ sadekamevādvitīyamityetadvivakṣitam /
analyzed: atha vā avivakṣitaḥ iha sṛṣṭi kramaḥ satkāryam idam sarvam atas sat ekam eva advitīyam iti etat vivakṣitam
translated: Or, the order of creation is not intended here. This entire universe is the effect of the existent. Therefore, the existent alone is one without a second - this is what is intended.

analyzed: mṛd ādi dṛṣṭāntāt
translated: From the examples of clay and so on.

analyzed: athavā trivṛt karaṇasya vivakṣita tvāt tejaḥ bannānām eva sṛṣṭim ācaṣṭe
translated: Or, because the threefold creation is intended, he describes the creation of fire, water and food only.

original: teja iti prasiddhaṃ loke dagdhṛ paktṛ prakāśakaṃ rohitaṃ ceti /
analyzed: tejaḥ iti prasiddham loke dagdhṛ paktṛ prakāśakam rohitam ca iti
translated: Fire is well-known in the world as the burner, the cooker, the illuminator, and the red.

analyzed: tat sat sṛṣṭam tejaḥ aikṣata tejaḥ rūpa saṃsthitam sat aikṣata iti arthaḥ
translated: That being, having created fire, looked upon it. The meaning is that being, abiding in the form of fire, looked upon it.

analyzed: bahu syām prajāyeya iti pūrvavat
translated: As before, (it thought), Let me become many, let me be born.

analyzed: tat apaḥ sṛjata
translated: It created water.

original: āpo dravāḥ snigdhāḥ syandinyaḥ śuklāśceti prasiddhā loke /
analyzed: āpaḥ dravāḥ snigdhāḥ syandinyaḥ śuklāḥ ca iti prasiddhāḥ loke
translated: Water is well-known in the world as the liquid, the slimy, the flowing, and the white.

original: yasmāttejasaḥ kāryabhūtā āpastasmādyatra kvaca deśe kāle vā śocati santapyate svedate prasvidyate vā puruṣastejasa eva tattadā'po 'dhijāyante🔽tā āpa aikṣanta bahvayaḥ syāma prajāyemahīti tā annamasṛjanta tasmādyatra kva ca varṣati tadeva bhūyiṣṭhamannaṃ bhavatyadbhya eva tadadhyannādyaṃ
analyzed: yasmāt tejasaḥ kārya bhūtāḥ āpaḥ tasmāt yatra kva ca deśe kāle vā śocati santapyate svedate prasvidyate vā puruṣaḥ tejasaḥ eva tat tat āpaḥ dhijāyante  tāḥ āpaḥ aikṣanta bahvayaḥ syāma prajāyemahi iti tāḥ annam asṛjanta tasmāt yatra kva ca varṣati tat eva bhūyiṣṭham annam bhavati adbhyaḥ eva tat adhi annādyam
translated: Since water is the effect of fire, wherever a person is heated, scorched, sweats, or perspires, from that fire water is born.

analyzed: jāyate
translated: Those waters looked (as before), Let us become many, let us be born. They created food. Therefore, wherever it rains, there food becomes most abundant. From water alone, food is born.

analyzed: tāḥ āpaḥ aikṣanta pūrvavat eva ap ākāra saṃsthitam sat aikṣata iti arthaḥ
translated: Those waters looked (as before), the meaning is that being, abiding in the form of water, looked upon it.

original: bahvayaḥ prabhūtāḥ syāma bhavema prajāyemahi utpadyemahoti /
analyzed: bahvayaḥ prabhūtāḥ syāma bhavema prajāyemahi utpadyemahi uti
translated: May we be many, may we be prosperous, may we be born, may we be produced.

analyzed: tāḥ annam asṛjanta pṛthivī lakṣaṇam
translated: They created food, characterized by earth.

original: pārthivaṃ hyannaṃ yasmādapkāryamannaṃ tasmādyatra kva ca varṣati deśe tattatraiva bhūyiṣṭhaṃ prabūtamannaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: pārthivam hi annam yasmāt ap kāryam annam tasmāt yatra kva ca varṣati deśe tat tatra eva bhūyiṣṭham prabūtam annam bhavati
translated: Food is of the nature of earth, because food is the effect of water. Therefore, wherever it rains, in that place there is the most abundant food.

analyzed: atas dbhyaḥ eva tat annādyam adhijāyate
translated: Therefore, that food is produced from water itself.

original: tā annamasṛjanteti pṛthivyuktā pūrvamiha tu dṛṣṭānte 'nnaṃ ca tadādyaṃ ceti viśeṣaṇādvrīhiyavādyā ucyante /
analyzed: tāḥ annam asṛjanta iti pṛthivī uktā pūrvam iha tu dṛṣṭānte nnam ca tat ādyam ca iti viśeṣaṇāt vrīhi yava ādyāḥ ucyante
translated: They created food - earth was mentioned earlier. But here in the example, because of the qualification that which is food and is primary, rice and barley are meant.

original: annaṃ ca guru sthiraṃ dhāraṇaṃ kṛṣṇaṃ ca rūpataḥ prasiddham /
analyzed: annam ca guru sthiram dhāraṇam kṛṣṇam ca rūpataḥ prasiddham
translated: And food is known to be heavy, stable, supporting, and black in color.

original: nanu tejaḥ prabhṛtiṣvīkṣaṇaṃ na gamyate hiṃsādipratiṣedhābhāvāttrāsādikāryānupalambhācca tatra kathaṃ tatteja aikṣatetyādi /
analyzed: nanu tejaḥ prabhṛtiṣu īkṣaṇam na gamyate hiṃsā ādi pratiṣedha abhāvāt trāsa ādi kārya anupalambhāt ca tatra katham tat tejaḥ aikṣata ityādi
translated: But in fire and so on, seeing is not understood, because there is no prohibition of injury etc., and because the effect such as fear is not perceived. So how can it be said that that fire saw and so on?

analyzed: na iṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: īkṣitṛkāraṇapariṇāmatvāttejaḥ prabhṛtīnāṃ sata ivekṣiturniyatakramaviśiṣṭakāryotpādakatvāt tejaḥ prabhṛtīkṣata ivekṣata ityucyate bhūtam /
analyzed: īkṣitṛ kāraṇa pariṇāma tvāt tejaḥ prabhṛtīnām sataḥ iva īkṣituḥ niyata krama viśiṣṭa kārya utpādaka tvāt tejaḥ prabhṛti īkṣate iva īkṣate iti ucyate bhūtam
translated: Because fire and so on are the transformation of the seeing cause, they are said to see like the seer, because they produce effects with a specific order, as if they were seeing. The element is said to see like the seer.

analyzed: nanu sataḥ api upacaritam eva īkṣitṛ tvam na
translated: But even if it exists, the state of being the seer is figurative. No.

analyzed: sat īkṣaṇasya kevala śabda gamya tvāt na śakyam upacaritam kalpayitum
translated: Because the seeing of the existent is understood by the word 'kevalam' (alone), it cannot be imagined to be figurative.

original: tejaḥ prabhṛtīnāṃ tvanumīyate mukhyekṣaṇābhāva iti yuktamupacaritaṃ kalpayitum /
analyzed: tejaḥ prabhṛtīnām tu anumīyate mukhya īkṣaṇa abhāvaḥ iti yuktam upacaritam kalpayitum
translated: But in the case of light etc., the absence of primary seeing is inferred, so it is proper to imagine it to be figurative.

analyzed: nanu sataḥ api mṛd vat kāraṇa tvāt acetana tvam śakyam anumātum
translated: But even if it exists, like clay, the state of being non-intelligent can be inferred from being a cause.

analyzed: atas pradhānasya eva acetanasya sataḥ cetanā artha tvāt niyata kāla krama viśiṣṭa kārya utpādaka tvāt ca aikṣata iva aikṣata iti śakyam anumātum upacaritam eva īkṣaṇam
translated: Therefore, it is possible to infer that the existent, which is non-intelligent like primordial matter, is for the sake of the intelligent, and produces effects with a specific time sequence, so the seeing is figurative, as if it were seeing.

analyzed: dṛṣṭaḥ ca loke cetane cetana vat upacāraḥ
translated: And figurative usage of the intelligent as if it were non-intelligent is seen in the world.

original: yathā kūlaṃ pipatiṣatīti tadvatsato 'pi syāt / na /
analyzed: yathā kūlam pipatiṣati iti tadvat sataḥ pi syāt na
translated: Just as one says 'the bank is falling', so it may be for the existent. No.

analyzed: tat satyam saḥ ātmā iti tasmin ātma upadeśāt
translated: Because in that, it is taught as the self, 'That is the truth, that is the self.'

original: ātmopadeśo 'pyupacarita iti cedyathā mamā'tmā bhadrasena iti ātmanaḥ sarvārthakāriṇyanātmanyātmopacārastadvat / na /
analyzed: ātma upadeśaḥ u pi upacaritaḥ iti ced yathā mama ātmā bhadrasenaḥ iti ātmanaḥ sarva artha kāriṇi anātmani ātma upacāraḥ tadvat na
translated: If it is argued that the teaching of the self is also figurative, like in 'Bhadra-sena is my self', where the self, which is the doer of all things, is figuratively used for the non-self, it is not so.

original: sadasmīti satsatyābhisandhasyatasya tāvadeva ciram iti mokṣopadeśāt /
analyzed: sat asmi iti tāvat eva ciram iti mokṣa upadeśāt
translated: Because of the teaching of liberation: As long as one thinks 'I am', only so long is there the long night (of ignorance). (Br. U. 4. 4. 22). When one thinks 'I am', thinking of the real Self, then there is liberation.

analyzed: saḥ u pi upacāraḥ iti ced
translated: If it be said that this also is figurative,

original: yathā loke grāmaṃ gantuṃ prasthitaḥ prāptavānahaṃ grāmamiti brūyāt tvarāpekṣayā tadvat / na /

translated: Just as in the world, one who has set out to go to a village might say, 'I have reached the village,' in consideration of speed, so also is this. No.

analyzed: yena vijñātena a vijñātam vijñātam bhavati iti upakramāt
translated: Because of the introduction: 'By knowing which the unknown becomes known.'

analyzed: sati etasmin vijñāte sarvam vijñātam bhavati tad ananya tvāt sarvasya advitīya vacanāt ca
translated: When this is known, everything becomes known, because of non-difference from that, and because of the statement of non-duality.

original: na cānyadvijñātavyamavaśiṣṭaṃ śrāvitaṃ śrutyānumeyaṃ vā liṅgato 'sti yena mokṣopadeśa upacaritaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na ca anyat vijñātavyam avaśiṣṭam śrāvitam śrutyā anumeyam vā liṅgataḥ sti yena mokṣa upadeśaḥ upacaritaḥ syāt
translated: And there is no other thing to be known, declared by scripture or to be inferred from indications, by which the teaching of liberation could be figurative.

original: sarvasya ca prapāṭhakārthasyopacaritatvaparikalpanāyāṃ vṛthā śramaḥ parikalpayituḥ syātpuruṣārthasādhanavijñānasya tarkeṇaivādhigatatvāttasya
analyzed: sarvasya ca prapāṭhaka arthasya upacarita tva parikalpanāyām vṛthā śramaḥ parikalpayituḥ syāt puruṣa artha sādhana vijñānasya tarkeṇa eva adhigata tvāt tasya
translated: And if one imagines that the whole meaning of the entire text is figurative, then the imagination of the one who imagines would be in vain, because the means of knowing the goal of man is already understood by reasoning.

analyzed: tasmāt veda prāmāṇyāt na śruta artha parityāgaḥ
translated: Therefore, because of the authoritativeness of the Veda, there should be no abandoning of the understood meaning.

analyzed: atas cetanāvat kāraṇam jagataḥ iti siddham
translated: And from this it follows that the cause of the world is an intelligent Being.

analyzed: iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya dvitīyaḥ khaṇḍaḥ  start chup
translated: Thus ends the Second Section of the Sixth Chapter in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: teṣām khalu eṣām bhūtānām trīṇi eva bījāni bhavanti āṇḍa jam jīva jam udbhijjam iti
translated: Now, of these beings, there are only three sources: the egg-born, the viviparous, and the sweat-born.

original: teṣāṃ jīvāviṣṭānāṃ khalveṣāṃ pakṣyādīnāṃ bhūtānāmeṣāmiti pratyakṣanirdeśānna
analyzed: teṣām jīva āviṣṭānām khalu eṣām pakṣi ādīnām bhūtānām eṣām iti pratyakṣa nirdeśāt na
translated: Of these beings, the birds and so on, which are possessed by the living soul, this is the direct statement.

original: tu tejaḥprabhṛtīnāṃ teṣāṃ trivṛtkaraṇasya vakṣyamāṇatvādasati trivṛtkarame pratyakṣanirdeśānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: tu tejaḥ prabhṛtīnām teṣām trivṛtkaraṇasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt asati trivṛtkarame pratyakṣa nirdeśa anupapattiḥ
translated: But not for fire and so on, because their threefold nature is going to be stated. Without the threefold nature, the direct statement is not possible.

translated: What are they? It is said:🔽The egg-born is born from the egg, the egg-born is the egg-born, such as birds and so on.

analyzed: pakṣi sarpa ādibhyaḥ hi pakṣi sarpa ādayaḥ jāyamānāḥ dṛśyante
translated: For birds, snakes and so on, birds, snakes and so on are seen to be born.

original: tena pakṣī pakṣiṇāṃ bījaṃ sarpaḥ sarpāṇāṃ tathānyadapyaṇḍājjātaṃ tajjātīyānāṃ bījamityarthaḥ /

translated: Therefore, a bird is the seed of birds, a snake of snakes, and similarly, anything born from an egg is the seed of its own kind.

analyzed: nanu aṇḍāt jātam aṇḍa jam ucyate ṇḍam eva bījam iti yuktam katham aṇḍa jam bījam ucyate

translated: This would be true if the Veda were dependent on your will. But the Veda is independent. Therefore, it says that what is born from an egg etc. is the seed, not the egg etc.

analyzed: dṛśyate ca aṇḍaja ādi abhāve tad jātīya santati abhāvaḥ na aṇḍa ādi abhāve
translated: And it is seen that in the absence of what is born from an egg etc., there is absence of continuity of that kind, not in the absence of the egg etc.

analyzed: atas ṇḍaja ādīni eva bījāni aṇḍaja ādīnām
translated: Therefore, what is born from an egg etc. are the seeds of what is born from an egg etc.

translated: Similarly, what is born from a living being is 'born from a living being', which is viviparous, such as humans, cattle etc.🔽What is born from a seed is 'born from a seed', which is a plant. analyzed: sveda ja saṃśoka jayoḥ aṇḍa ja udbhid jayoḥ eva yathāsambhavam antarbhāvaḥ
translated: What is born from sweat and what is born from moisture are respectively included within what is born from an egg and what is born from a seed, as appropriate.

analyzed: evam hi avadhāraṇam trīṇi eva bījāni iti upapannam bhavati
translated: For thus the restriction to three seeds becomes proper.🔽Thus, then, the creation of the five-fold primary elements is described.

translated: Now, I, having entered these three deities beginning with fire, as mentioned,

analyzed: nanu na yuktam idam asaṃsāriṇyāḥ sarvajñāyāḥ devatāyāḥ buddhi pūrvakam aneka śata sahasra anartha āśrayam deham anupraviśya duḥkham anubhaviṣyāmi iti saṅkalpanam anupraveśaḥ ca

original: kiṃ punaratra ṣaṣṭhe vākyapramāṇena janitaṃ phalam /
analyzed: kim punar atra ṣaṣṭhe vākya pramāṇena janitam phalam
translated: What, again, is the result produced here in the sixth by the means of valid knowledge in the form of a sentence?

original: ātmani kartṛtvabhoktṛtvayoradhikṛtatvavijñānanivṛttistasya phalaṃ yaṃ vayamavocāma tvaṃśabdavācyamarthaṃ śrotuṃ mantuṃ cādhikṛtamavijñātavijñānaphalārtham
analyzed: ātmani kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tvayoḥ adhikṛta tva vijñāna nivṛttiḥ tasya phalam yam vayam avocāma tvad śabda vācyam artham śrotum mantum ca adhikṛtam avijñāta vijñāna phala artham
translated: The result of that is the cessation of the knowledge of being entitled to the states of being an agent and an enjoyer in the self, which we have said is the object denoted by the word 'you', entitled to hear and reflect upon, for the sake of the result in the form of the knowledge of the unknown.

analyzed: prāk ca etasmāt vijñānāt aham evam kariṣyāmi agnihotra ādīni karmāṇi aham atra adhikṛtaḥ
translated: And before this knowledge, he thought, 'I shall perform such actions as Agnihotra etc., I am entitled to this.

original: eṣāṃ ca karmaṇāṃ phalamihāmutra ca bhokṣye kṛteṣu vā karmasu kṛtakartavyaḥ syāmityevaṃ
analyzed: eṣām ca karmaṇām phalam iha amutra ca bhokṣye kṛteṣu vā karmasu kṛta kartavyaḥ syām iti evam
translated: And I shall enjoy the fruits of these actions here and hereafter, or having performed the actions, I shall become one who has done what was to be done.' Thus

original: kartṛtvabhoktṛtvayoradhikṛto 'smītyātmani yadvijñānamabhūttattasya yatsajjagato mūlamekamevādvitīyaṃ🔽tattvamasītyanena vākyena pratibuddhasya nivartate /
analyzed: kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tvayoḥ smi iti ātmani yat vijñānam abhūt tat tasya yat sat jagataḥ mūlam ekam eva advitīyam  tat tvam asi iti anena vākyena pratibuddhasya nivartate
translated: the knowledge that he is entitled to the states of being an agent and an enjoyer in the self, that ceases for him by the sentence 'That thou art', which is🔽the one and only root of this universe, which is non-dual.

analyzed: virodhāt
translated: Because of contradiction.

original: na hyekasminnadvitīya ātmanyayamahamasmīti vijñāte mamedamanyadanena kartavyamidaṃ kṛtvāsya phalaṃ bhokṣya iti vā bhedavijñānamupapadyate /
analyzed: na hi ekasmin advitīye ātmani ayam aham asmi iti vijñāte mama idam anyat anena kartavyam idam kṛtvā asya phalam bhokṣye iti vā bheda vijñānam upapadyate
translated: For when one knows the one, the non-dual Self, as 'I am this', the knowledge of difference, 'this is mine, by this I must act, having done this, I shall enjoy its fruit', is not possible.

analyzed: tasmāt sat satya advitīya ātma vijñāne vikāra anṛta jīva ātma vijñānam nivartate iti yuktam
translated: Therefore, it is right that the knowledge of the changing, unreal individual Self ceases when there is the knowledge of the real, non-dual Self.

original: nanu tattvamasītyatra tvaṃśabdavācyer'the sadbuddhirādhitsyate yathā'dityamana ādiṣu brahmādibuddhiḥ /
analyzed: nanu tat tvam asi iti atra tvaṃśabda vācya ṛthe sat buddhiḥ ādhitsyate yathā āditya manaḥ ādiṣu brahma ādi buddhiḥ
translated: But here in 'That thou art', the idea of the real is to be superimposed on the object denoted by the word 'thou', just as the idea of Brahman etc. is superimposed on the sun etc.,

original: yathā ca loke pratimādiṣu viṣṇvādibuddhistadvannatu sadeva tvamiti /
analyzed: yathā ca loke pratimā ādiṣu viṣṇu ādi buddhiḥ tadvat na tu sat eva tvam iti
translated: or just as the idea of Vishnu etc. is superimposed on images etc. in the world, but not that 'thou' is the real.

original: yadi sadeva śvetaketuḥ syātkathamātmānaṃ na vijānīyādyena tasmai tattvamasītyupadiśyate / na /
analyzed: yadi sat eva śvetaketuḥ syāt katham ātmānam na vijānīyāt yena tasmai tat tvam asi iti upadiśyate na
translated: If Svetashvatara were the real, how could he not know the Self, for whose sake it is taught to him 'That thou art'? No.

analyzed: āditya ādi vākya vailakṣaṇyāt
translated: Because of the difference from the statements about the sun etc.

analyzed: ādityaḥ brahma ityādau itiśabda vyavadhānāt na sākṣāt brahmatvam gamyate
translated: In 'The sun is Brahman' etc., because of the intervention of the word 'is', Brahmanhood is not directly understood.

original: rūpādimattvāccā'dityādīnāmākāśamanasoścetiśabdavyavadhānādevābrahmatvamiha tu sata eveha praveśaṃ darśayitvā tattvamasīti niraṅkuśaṃ sadātmabhāvamupadiśati
analyzed: rūpa ādimat tvāt ca āditya ādīnām ākāśa manasoḥ ca iti śabda vyavadhānāt eva a brahmatvam iha tu sataḥ eva iha praveśam darśayitvā tat tvam asi iti niraṅkuśam sat ātma bhāvam upadiśati
translated: And because Āditya and the rest are possessed of form and so on, and because Ākāśa and Manas are separated by the word ‘ca’, therefore they are not Brahman. But here, after having shown that ‘of Being only there is the entering in here’, it teaches, by means of the words ‘That thou art’, the nature of Being, without any restraint.

original: nanu parākramādiguṇaḥ siṃho 'si tvamitivattattvamasīti syāt / na /
analyzed: nanu parākrama ādi guṇaḥ siṃhaḥ si tvam iti vat tat tvam asi iti syāt na
translated: But just as one says ‘You are a lion, having the qualities of prowess and the like’, so here also (the teacher may say) ‘You are That, i.e., Brahman, having the qualities of omniscience and the like.’ No.

analyzed: mṛd ādi vat sat ekam eva advitīyam satyam iti upadeśāt
translated: Because the teaching is that ‘Being only is all this, one, without a second, and true’, like clay and the rest.

analyzed: na ca upacāra vijñānāt tasya tāvat eva ciram iti sat sampattiḥ ūpadiśyeta
translated: And if the knowledge (of the disciple) were figurative, then the statement ‘For him there is but delay as long as (final) release (is not attained)’ would not be possible, which refers to the attainment of Being.

analyzed: mṛṣātvāt upacāra vijñānasya
translated: Because the figurative knowledge is false.

analyzed: tvam indraḥ si yamaḥ itivat  nā api stutiḥ anupāsya tvāt śvetaketoḥ
translated: Just as (the statement) ‘You are Indra, you are Yama’ (is false).🔽Nor is it praise, because Śvetaketu is not to be meditated upon.

analyzed: na api sat śvetaketu tva upadeśena stūyeta
translated: Nor would he be praised by the teaching that ‘Śvetaketu is Being’.

original: na hi rājā dāsastvamiti stutyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na hi rājā dāsaḥ tvam iti stutyaḥ syāt
translated: For one is not praised by being called ‘You are a king’s slave’.

original: nāpi sataḥ sarvātmana ekadeśanirodho yuktastattvamasīti deśādhipateriva grāmādhyakṣastvamiti /
analyzed: na api sataḥ sarvātmanaḥ eka deśa nirodhaḥ yuktaḥ tat tvam asi iti deśa adhipateḥ iva grāma adhyakṣaḥ tvam iti
translated: Nor is it proper to restrict a part of Being, which is all, by saying ‘That thou art’, just as one restricts the governor of a district by saying ‘You are the headman of a village’, like a king who is the lord of a country.

analyzed: na ca anyā gatiḥ iha sat ātmatva upadeśāt artha antara bhūtā sambhavati
translated: And there is no other way here apart from the teaching of the nature of Being.

original: nanu sadasmītibuddhimātramiha kartavyatayā codyate na tvajñātaṃ sadasīti jñāpyata iti cet /
analyzed: nanu sat asmi iti buddhi mātram iha kartavya tayā codyate na tu ajñātam sat asi iti jñāpyate iti ced
translated: If it be said that here only the idea that 'I am Being' is enjoined as something to be done, and not that 'I am Being' which is not known is to be made known, [we reply:]

analyzed: nanu asmin pakṣe pi aśrutam śrutam bhavati ityādi anupapannam
translated: No. Even in this case, it would be improper to say that what is not heard becomes heard, and so on.

analyzed: na sat asmi iti buddhi vidheḥ stuti artha tvāt
translated: No. Because the injunction to have the idea that 'I am Being' is for the purpose of praise.

original: na / ācāryavānpuruṣo veda tasya tāvadeva ciramityupadeśāt /
analyzed: na ācāryavān puruṣaḥ veda tasya tāvat eva ciram iti upadeśāt
translated: No. Because of the teaching: 'A person who has a teacher knows. For him, that alone is for a long time.'

original: yadi hi sadasmīti buddhimātraṃ kartavyatayā vidhīyate na tu tvaṃśabdavācyasya sadrūpatvameva tadā nā'cāryavānvedeti jñānopāyopadeśo vācyaḥ
analyzed: yadi hi sat asmi iti buddhi mātram kartavyatayā vidhīyate na tu tvaṃśabda vācyasya sat rūpa tvam eva tadā na ācāryavān veda iti jñāna upāya upadeśaḥ vācyaḥ
translated: For if only the idea that 'I am Being' is enjoined as something to be done, and not the fact that what is denoted by the word 'you' is of the nature of Being, then the teaching of the means of knowledge should not be stated:

analyzed: yathā agnihotram juhuyāt iti evamādiṣu artha prāptam eva ācāryavat tvam iti tadvat
translated: 'A person who has a teacher knows.' Just as in statements like 'One should offer the Agnihotra', having a teacher is already implied, so it is in this case.

original: tasya tāvadeva ciramiti ca kṣepakaraṇaṃ na yuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tasya tāvat eva ciram iti ca kṣepa karaṇam na yuktam syāt
translated: And it would not be proper to dismiss [the idea of the self] with the words 'That alone is for a long time'.

analyzed: sat ātma tattve vijñāte sakṛt buddhi mātra karaṇe mokṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: For if the truth of Being as the self is not known, and the idea [that 'I am Being'] is produced only once, there would be the undesirable consequence of liberation.

original: na ca tattvamasītyukte nāhaṃ saditipramāṇavākyajanitā buddhīrnivartayituṃ śakyā notpanneti vā śakyaṃ vaktum /
analyzed: na ca tat tvam asi iti ukte na aham sat iti pramāṇa vākya janitāḥ buddhīḥ nivartayitum śakyā nā utpannā iti vā śakyam vaktum
translated: And it cannot be said that when 'That thou art' is stated, the idea produced by the authoritative statement 'I am Being' cannot be reversed, or that it cannot be said to have arisen.

analyzed: sarva upaniṣad vākyānām tad para tayā eva upakṣayāt
translated: Because all the statements of the Upaniṣads are only subsidiary to that.

analyzed: yathā agnihotra ādi vidhi janita agnihotra ādi kartavya tā buddhīnām atathārtha tvam anutpanna tvam vā na śakyate vaktum tadvat
translated: Just as it cannot be said that the cognitions of the duty to perform agnihotra etc. generated by the injunctions of agnihotra etc. are not true or non-existent, so it is.

original: yattūktaṃ sadātmā sannātmānaṃ kathaṃ na jānīyāditi /
analyzed: yat tu uktam sat ātmā sanna ātmānam katham na jānīyāt iti
translated: But it has been said: How can the existent Self not know its own existence?

analyzed: na asau doṣaḥ
translated: That is not a fault.

original: kāryakaraṇasaṅghātavyatirikto 'haṃ jīvaḥ kartā bhoktetyapi svabhāvataḥ prāṇināṃ vijñānādarśanātkisu tasya sadātmavijñānam /
analyzed: kārya karaṇa saṅghāta vyatiriktaḥ ham jīvaḥ kartā bhoktā iti api svabhāvataḥ prāṇinām vijñāna adarśanāt kisu tasya sat ātma vijñānam
translated: Even though living beings naturally know I am the doer, the enjoyer, separate from the aggregate of body and organs, how can there be the knowledge of its own existence?

original: kathamevaṃ vyatiriktavijñāne sati teṣāṃ kartṛtvādivijñānaṃ sambhavati dṛśyate ca /
analyzed: katham evam vyatirikta vijñāne sati teṣām kartṛ tva ādi vijñānam sambhavati dṛśyate ca
translated: How can the knowledge of its being the doer etc. be possible when there is the knowledge of being separate? And it is seen.

analyzed: tadvat tasya api deha ādiṣu ātma buddhi tvāt na syāt sat ātma vijñānam
translated: In the same way, for it too, because of the notion of Self in the body etc., there would not be the knowledge of its own existence.

original: tasmādvikārānṛtādhikṛtajīvātmavijñānanivartakamevedaṃ vākyaṃ tattvamasīti siddhamiti // //🔽iti cchāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭhādhyāyasya ṣoḍaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
analyzed: tasmāt vikāra anṛta adhikṛta jīvātma vijñāna nivartakam eva idam vākyam tat tvam asi iti siddham iti  iti chāndogyopaniṣadi ṣaṣṭha adhyāyasya ṣoḍaśaḥ khaṇḍaḥ
translated: Therefore, this statement That thou art is established as only removing the knowledge of the individual Self, which is based on modifications and untruth.🔽Thus ends the sixteenth section in the sixth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: iti chāndogya upaniṣad brāhmaṇe ṣaṣṭhaḥ udhyāyaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: Thus ends the sixth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad-Brāhmaṇa.

analyzed: atha saptamaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Now, the seventh chapter.

analyzed: start chup
translated: Begins the ChUp.

original: adhīhi bhagava iti hopasasāda sanatkumāraṃ nāradaḥ /
analyzed: adhīhi bhagavaḥ iti ha upasasāda sanatkumāram nāradaḥ
translated: Narada approached Sanatkumara, saying, Venerable Sir, teach me.

original: taṃ hovāca yad vettha tena mopasīda /
analyzed: tam ha uvāca yat vettha tena mā upasīda
translated: He said to him, Approach me with what you know.

analyzed: tatas te ūrdhvam vakṣyāmi iti
translated: Then I will tell you what is beyond that.

analyzed: sa ha uvāca
translated: He said:
The sixth chapter, which is mainly concerned with the teaching of the highest truth, is useful only by determining the oneness of the Self and Being.

original: na sator'vāgvikāralakṣaṇāni tattvāni nirdiṣṭānītyatastāni nāmādīni prāṇāntāni krameṇa
analyzed: na satoḥ vāc vikāra lakṣaṇāni tattvāni nirdiṣṭāni iti atas tāni nāma ādīni prāṇa antāni krameṇa
translated: The truths characterized by modifications below Being are not indicated. Therefore, he will indicate those, beginning with name and ending with vital breath,

original: nirdiśya taddvāreṇāpi bhūmākhyaṃ niratiśayaṃ tattvaṃ nirdekṣyāmīti śākhācandradarśanavaditīnaṃ
analyzed: nirdiśya tad dvāreṇa api bhūma ākhyam niratiśayam tattvam nirdekṣyāmi iti śākhā candra darśana vat itīnam
translated: and through that door, he will also indicate the highest truth called the Absolute. This is the intention, like seeing the branches and the moon.

analyzed: saptamam prapāṭhakam ārabhate
translated: He begins the seventh section.

original: anirdiṣṭeṣu hi sator'vāktattveṣu sanmātre ca nirdiṣṭe 'nyadapyavijñātaṃ syādityāśaṅkā kasyacitsyātsā mā bhūditi vā tāni nirdidikṣati /
analyzed: a nirdiṣṭeṣu hi satoḥ vāc tattveṣu sat mātre ca nirdiṣṭe syāt iti āśaṅkā kasyacid syāt sā mā bhūt iti vā tāni nirdidikṣati
translated: If the truths below Being and Being alone, which are not indicated, were indicated, something else might be unknown. Let this doubt of someone not arise. Or he indicates those.

original: athavā sopānārohaṇavatsthūlādārabhya sūkṣmaṃ sūkṣamataṃ ca buddhiviṣayaṃ jñāpayitvā tadatirikte svārājye 'bhiṣekṣyāmīti nāmādīni nirdidikṣati
analyzed: athavā sopāna ārohaṇa vat sthūlāt ārabhya sūkṣmam ca buddhi viṣayam jñāpayitvā tad atirikte svārājye bhiṣekṣyāmi iti nāma ādīni nirdidikṣati
translated: Or else, he is pointing out the names etc. with the intention that, just as one climbs a staircase starting from the top step and then goes to the top, similarly, having made known the objects of cognition starting from the gross and then the subtler and subtler, I will consecrate him in the sovereignty over that which is beyond that.

original: athavā nāmādyuttarottaraviśiṣṭāni tattvānyatitarāṃ ca teṣāmutkṛṣṭatamaṃ bhūmākhyaṃ tattvamiti tatstutyarthaṃ nāmādīnāṃ krameṇopanyāsaḥ /
analyzed: athavā nāma ādi uttarottara viśiṣṭāni tattvāni atitarām ca teṣām utkṛṣṭatamam bhūma ākhyam tattvam iti tad stuti artham nāma ādīnām krameṇa upanyāsaḥ
translated: Or else, the principles are progressively more and more excellent, starting from name etc., and the principle called the Absolute is the most excellent of them all. Therefore, the mention of name etc. in order is for the purpose of praising that.

analyzed: ākhyāyikā tu para vidyā stuti arthā
translated: The story is for the purpose of praising the supreme knowledge.

original: katham /🔽nārado devarṣiḥ kṛtakartavyaḥ sarvavidyo 'pi sannanātmajñatvācchuśocaiva kimu vaktavyamanyo 'lpavijjanturakṛtapuṇyātiśayo 'kṛtārtha iti /
analyzed: katham  nāradaḥ deva ṛṣiḥ kṛta kartavyaḥ sarva vidyaḥ sarva vidyaḥ san an ātma jña tvāt śuśoca eva kimu vaktavyam anyaḥ lpa vid jantuḥ akṛta puṇya atiśayaḥ kṛtārthaḥ iti
translated: How so?🔽Even though the divine sage Nārada had done what was to be done and knew everything, he still grieved because he did not know the Self. What need to speak of others, who are limited in knowledge, whose merit is not great, and who have not accomplished their purpose?

analyzed: athavā na anyat ātma jñānāt niratiśaya śreyaḥ sādhanam asti iti etad pradarśana artham sanatkumāra nārada ākhyāyikā ārabhyate
translated: Or else, the story of Sanatkumāra and Nārada is begun for the purpose of showing that there is no means of attaining the highest good other than the knowledge of the Self.

original: yena sarvavijñānasādhanaśaktisampannasyāpi nāradasya devarṣeḥ śreyo na babhūva yenottamābhijanavidyāvṛttasādhanaśaktisampattinimittābhi
analyzed: yena sarva vijñāna sādhana śakti sampannasya api nāradasya deva ṛṣeḥ śreyaḥ na babhūva yena uttama abhijana vidyā vṛtta sādhana śakti sampatti nimitta abhi
translated: By which, even for Narada, the divine sage, endowed with the power to accomplish all knowledge, there was no well-being. By which, the causes of excellence in birth, learning, conduct, and means to accomplish goals, were not attained.

analyzed: mānam hitvā prākṛta puruṣa vat sanatkumāram upasasāda śreyaḥ sādhana prāptaye prakhyāpitam
translated: By whom, even though endowed with the power to accomplish all knowledge, the divine sage Nārada did not attain well-being. By whom, setting aside pride caused by the possession of excellent birth, learning, conduct, and the means of accomplishment, he approached Sanatkumāra like an ordinary person, to attain the means of attaining well-being. Therefore,

analyzed: bhavati niratiśaya prāpti sādhana tvam ātma vidyāyāḥ iti
translated: it is proclaimed that the knowledge of the Self is the means of attaining the highest perfection.

analyzed: adhīhi adhīṣva bhagavān bha vid iti kila upasasāda
translated: He approached, saying, Teach, O Blessed One, you who are learned.

analyzed: adhīhi bhagavaḥ iti mantraḥ
translated: The mantra is Teach me, O Blessed One.

original: sanatkumāraṃ yogīśvaraṃ brahmiṣṭhaṃ nārada upasannavān /🔽taṃ nyāyata upasannaṃ hovāca yadātmaviṣaye kiñcidvettha tena tatprakhyāpanena māmupasīdedamahaṃ
analyzed: sanatkumāram yogi īśvaram brahmiṣṭham nāradaḥ upasannavān  tam nyāyataḥ upasannam ha uvāca yat ātma viṣaye kiñcid vettha tena tad prakhyāpanena mām upasīda idam aham
translated: Nārada approached the lord of yogis, the most Brahmanic Sanatkumāra.🔽To him who approached in the proper way, he said, Whatever you know about the Self, by proclaiming that, approach me, saying 'I know this.' Then I will teach you further knowledge above that.

original: jāna iti tato 'haṃ bhavato vijñānātte tubyamūrdhvaṃ vakṣyāmītyuktavati sa hovāca nāradaḥ // //🔽START ChUp / /
analyzed: jāne iti tatas ham bhavataḥ vijñānāt te tubyam ūrdhvam vakṣyāmi iti uktavati sa ha uvāca nāradaḥ  start chup
translated: When he said this, Nārada said:

original: ṛgvedaṃ bhagavo 'dhyemi yajurvedaṃ sāmavedam ātharvaṇaṃ caturtham itihāsapurāṇaṃ
analyzed: ṛgvedam bhagavaḥ dhyemi yajurvedam sāmavedam ātharvaṇam caturtham itihāsa purāṇam
translated: I study the Ṛg Veda, O Blessed One, the Yajur Veda, the Sāma Veda, the fourth one called Atharvan, the Itihāsa and Purāṇa,

original: pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vedaṃ pitryaṃ rāśiṃ daivaṃ nidhiṃ vākovākyam ekāyanaṃ devavidyāṃ
analyzed: pañcamam vedānām vedam pitryam rāśim daivam nidhim vākovākyam ekāyanam deva vidyām
translated: The fifth is the Veda of the Vedas, the science of the ancestors, the science of the stars, the treasure, the sayings of the sages, the one-way path, the knowledge of the gods,

original: brahmavidyāṃ bhūtavidyāṃ kṣatravidyāṃ nakṣatravidyāṃ sarpadevajanavidyām etad bhagavo
analyzed: brahma vidyām bhūta vidyām kṣatra vidyām nakṣatra vidyām sarpa deva jana vidyām etat bhagavaḥ
translated: the knowledge of Brahman, the knowledge of beings, the knowledge of the warrior class, the knowledge of the stars, the knowledge of serpents and gods. O revered one,

analyzed: dhyemi
translated: I study this...

original: ṛgvedaṃ bhagavo 'dhyemi smarāmi yadvettheti vijñānasya pṛṣṭatvāt /

translated: Food is that which is eaten. The consciousness of objects like sound is eaten for the enjoyment of the experiencer. analyzed: viṣaya vijñānam iti arthaḥ

translated: There, the 'sat' syllable is immortality, the existent Brahman, because it denotes immortality. The 's' syllable is indicated as ending with 't'.

analyzed: atha yat ti takāraḥ tat martyam

analyzed: saṃyate iva hi etena yamā lakṣyete

analyzed: ukta lakṣaṇaḥ yaḥ saṃprasādaḥ tasya svarūpam vakṣyamāṇaiḥ uktaiḥ ca guṇaiḥ punar stūyate brahmacarya sādhana saṃbandha artham
translated: Now, that Self, which has been described as the tranquil state of the mind, its nature is being praised again with the qualities that have been mentioned and will be mentioned, for the purpose of connecting it with the means of attaining Brahman.

original: kiṃviśṣṭaścāsau seturityāhanaitam setumātmānamahorātre sarvasya janimataḥ paricchedake satī naitaṃ tarataḥ /

translated: The idea is that just as other transmigrating beings are delimited by time characterized by day and night, this one is not delimited by time.

original: ata evainaṃ na jarā tarati na prāpnoti /

translated: Although the negation of impurity, etc. has already been stated by the passage beginning with the Self which is free from impurity, etc., still here this is the difference: the attainment of the object is negated by he does not cross over.
