original: yanmanyase 'kṣyādhārādilakṣaṇaḥ saṃprasādalakṣaṇa ātmā mayokto vināśamevāpīto bhavatīti /
analyzed: yat manyase kṣyā ādhāra ādi lakṣaṇaḥ saṃprasāda lakṣaṇaḥ ātmā mayā uktaḥ vināśam eva apītaḥ bhavati iti
translated: You think that the Self, which I have described as having the characteristics of the support of the eyes and so on, and as having the characteristics of deep sleep, goes to destruction itself.

analyzed: śṛṇu tatra kāraṇam
translated: Listen to the reason for that.

analyzed: yat idam śarīram vai tat etat martyam vināśi
translated: This body, indeed, is mortal, perishable.

analyzed: tat ca āttam mṛtyunā grastam satatam eva
translated: And that is always seized and swallowed by death.

original: kadācideva mriyata iti martyamityukte na tathā saṃtrāso bhavati yathā grastameva sadā vyāptameva mṛtyunetyukta iti vairāgyārthaṃ viśeṣa ityucyata
analyzed: kadācid eva mriyate iti martyam iti ukte na tathā saṃtrāsaḥ bhavati yathā grastam eva sadā vyāptam eva mṛtyunā iti uktaḥ iti vairāgya artham viśeṣaḥ iti ucyata
translated: When it is said that it dies only sometimes, there is not such fear as when it is said that it is always seized and pervaded by death. Thus, for the purpose of detachment, a distinction is stated.

analyzed: āttam mṛtyunā iti
translated: It is said that it is seized by death.

original: kathaṃ nāma dehābhimānato viraktaḥ sannivartata iti /
analyzed: katham nāma deha abhimānataḥ viraktaḥ san nivartate iti
translated: How can one become detached from the identification with the body and turn away?

analyzed: śarīram iti atra saha indriya manobhiḥ ucyate
translated: Here, the body is referred to along with the sense organs and the mind.

analyzed: tat śarīram asya saṃprasādasya tri sthāna tayā gamyamānasya amṛtasya maraṇa ādi deha ndriya manaḥ dharma varjitasya iti etat
translated: That body is of this pure consciousness, which is known through the three states, and is immortal, free from the qualities of the body, sense organs, and mind such as death.

original: amṛtasyetyanenaivāśarīratve siddhe punaraśarīrasyeti vacanaṃ vāyvādivatsāvayavatvamūrtimattve mā bhūtāmityātmanaḥ /
analyzed: amṛtasya iti anena eva aśarīra tve siddhe punar aśarīrasya iti vacanam vāyu ādi vat sāvayavatva mūrtimattve mā bhūtām iti ātmanaḥ
translated: Even though the state of being bodiless is established by the word immortal, the statement of the bodiless is made again to prevent the soul from having parts like air, etc. and being embodied.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ vā sataḥ īkṣituḥ tejaḥ banna ādi krameṇa utpannam adhiṣṭhānam
translated: Or, the soul, being the seer, is the basis of the creation in the order of fire, water, earth, etc.

analyzed: jīva rūpeṇa praviśya sat eva adhitiṣṭhati asmin iti vā adhiṣṭhānam
translated: Having entered as the individual soul, it presides over that which exists in it. Thus, it is the basis.

analyzed: yasya idam īdṛśam nityam eva mṛtyu grastam dharma adharma janita tvāt priya apriya vat adhiṣṭhānam tad adhiṣṭhitaḥ tadvān sa śarīraḥ bhavati
translated: He who has this kind of body, which is always seized by death, and which is the substratum of pleasure and pain born of Dharma and Adharma, is embodied, i.e., he has a body.

original: aśarīrasvabhāvasyā'tmanastadevāhaṃ śarīraṃ śarīrameva cāhamityavivekādātmabhāvaḥ saśarīratvaṃ ata eva saśarīraḥ sannātto grastaḥ priyāpriyābhyām
analyzed: aśarīra svabhāvasya ātmanaḥ tat eva aham śarīram śarīram eva ca aham iti avivekāt ātma bhāvaḥ sa śarīra tvam atas eva sa śarīraḥ san āttaḥ grastaḥ priya apriyābhyām
translated: The Self, which is of the nature of being bodiless, thinks that the body is the Self, and the Self is the body. Due to this non-discrimination, the Self has a body. Therefore, while having a body, he is seized, i.e., overwhelmed, by pleasure and pain.

analyzed: prasiddham etat
translated: This is well-known.

original: tasya ca na vai saśarīrasya sataḥ priyāpriyayorbāhyaviṣayasaṃyogaviyoganimittayorbāhyaviṣayasaṃyogaviyogau mameti manyamānasyāpahatirvināśa
analyzed: tasya ca na vai sa śarīrasya sataḥ priya apriyayoḥ bāhya viṣaya saṃyoga viyoga nimittayoḥ bāhya viṣaya saṃyoga viyogau mama iti manyamānasya apahatiḥ vināśa
translated: And for him who has a body, the destruction, i.e., the cutting off, of pleasure and pain, which are caused by the union and separation with external objects, does not exist, thinking that the union and separation with external objects are his.

analyzed: ucchedaḥ santati rūpayoḥ na asti iti
translated: This is because they are of the nature of a continuum.

original: taṃ punardehābhimānādaśarīrasvarūpavijñānena vinartitāvivekajñānaśarīraṃ santaṃ priyāpriye na spṛśataḥ /
analyzed: tam punar deha abhimānāt aśarīra sva rūpa vijñānena vinartita aviveka jñāna śarīram santam priya apriye na spṛśataḥ
translated: Moreover, for him whose body of discrimination, i.e., knowledge, is destroyed by the ignorance of the bodiless nature of the Self due to the identification with the body, pleasure and pain do not touch.

original: spṛśiḥ pratyekaṃ saṃbadhyata iti priyaṃ na spṛśatyapriyaṃ na spṛśatīti vākyadvayaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: spṛśiḥ pratyekam saṃbadhyate iti priyam na spṛśati apriyam na spṛśati iti vākya dvayam bhavati
translated: The word spṛśiḥ is connected with each, so there are two sentences: pleasure does not touch and pain does not touch.

analyzed: na mleccha aśuci adhārmikaiḥ saha saṃbhāṣeta iti yadvat
translated: Just as one does not converse with barbarians, the impure, or the unrighteous.

analyzed: dharma adharma kārye hi te
translated: For they are the effects of dharma and adharma.

original: aśarīratā tu svarūpamiti tatra dharmādharmayorasaṃbhavāttatkāryabhāvo dūrata evetyato na priyāpriye spṛśataḥ /
analyzed: aśarīra tā tu svarūpam iti tatra dharma adharmayoḥ asaṃbhavāt tad kārya bhāvaḥ dūratas eva iti atas na priya apriye spṛśataḥ
translated: But the state of being bodiless is the very nature of the Self. Therefore, since dharma and adharma are impossible there, the existence of their effects, pleasure and pain, is far away. Hence pleasure and pain do not touch it.

original: nanu yadi priyamapyaśarīraṃ na spṛśatīti yanmaghavatoktaṃ suṣuptastho vināśamevāpīto bhavatīti tadevehāpyāpannam /
analyzed: nanu yadi priyam api aśarīram na spṛśati iti yat maghavatā uktam suṣupta sthaḥ vināśam eva apītaḥ bhavati iti tat eva iha api āpannam
translated: But if pleasure also does not touch the bodiless, then what is stated by Indra - He who is in deep sleep goes to destruction - would apply here also.

original: naiṣa doṣaḥ dharmādharmakāryayoḥ śarīrasaṃbandhinoḥ priyāpriyayoḥ pratiṣedhasya vivakṣitatvāt aśarīraṃ na priyāpriye spṛśata iti /🔽āgamāpāyinorhi sparśaśabdo dṛṣṭo yathā śītasparśa uṣṇasparśa iti na tvagneruṣṇaprakāśayoḥ
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ dharma adharma kāryayoḥ śarīra saṃbandhinoḥ priya apriyayoḥ pratiṣedhasya vivakṣita tvāt aśarīram na priya apriye spṛśate iti  āgama apāyinoḥ hi sparśa śabdaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ yathā śīta sparśe uṣṇa sparśe iti na tu agneḥ uṣṇa prakāśayoḥ
translated: This is not a fault, because the negation of pleasure and pain, which are connected with the body and are the effects of dharma and adharma, is intended - The bodiless is not touched by pleasure and pain.🔽For the word touch is seen to refer to what comes and goes, as in the touch of cold, the touch of heat. It is not said the touch of fire for heat and light, which are the very nature of fire.

analyzed: svabhāva bhūtayoḥ agninā sparśaḥ iti bhavati tathā agneḥ savituḥ vā uṣṇa prakāśa vat sva rūpa bhūtasya ānandasya
translated: Similarly, for Brahman, whose nature is bliss, which is like the heat and light of fire,

original: priyasyāpi neha pratiṣedhaḥvijñānamānandaṃ brahma ānando brahmaityādiśrutibhyaḥ /
analyzed: priyasya api na iha pratiṣedhaḥ vijñānam ānandam brahma ānandaḥ brahma etyādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: Nor is there any prohibition of the beloved here, because of the Upanisadic texts such as Knowledge is bliss, Brahman is bliss, Brahman is, etc.

analyzed: iha api bhūmā eva sukham iti ukta tvāt
translated: And here also, because it is said that Bliss itself is the beloved.

original: nanu bhūmnaḥ priyasyaikatve 'saṃvedyatvātsvarūpeṇa vā nityasaṃvedyatvānnirviśeṣateti nendrasya tadiṣṭam /
analyzed: nanu bhūmnaḥ priyasya eka tve saṃvedya tvāt svarūpeṇa vā nitya saṃvedya tvāt nirviśeṣa tā iti nā indrasya tat iṣṭam
translated: But if the beloved Brahman is one, then it is not an object of experience, or if it is always an object of experience by its own nature, then it is without any distinction. This is not accepted by Indra.

original: nāha khalvayaṃ saṃpratyātmānaṃ jānātyayamahamasmīti no evomāni bhūtāni vināśamevāpīto bhavati nāhamatra bhogyaṃ paśyāmiityuktatvāt /🔽taddhondrasyeṣṭaṃ yadbhatāni cā'tmānaṃ ca jānāti na cāpriyaṃ kiñcidvetti sa sarvāṃśca🔽lokānāpnoti sarvāṃśca kāmānyena jñānena satyametadiṣṭamindrasyemāni bhūtāni matto
analyzed: na aha khalu ayam saṃprati ātmānam jānāti ayam aham asmi iti na u eva umāni bhūtāni vināśam eva apītaḥ bhavati na aham atra bhogyam paśyāmi iti ukta tvāt  tat ha undrasya iṣṭam yat bhatāni ca ātmānam ca jānāti na ca apriyam kiñcid vetti sa sarvān ca  lokān āpnoti sarvān ca kāmān yena jñānena satyam etat iṣṭam indrasya imāni bhūtāni mattaḥ
translated: Verily, he does not now know the Self as 'I am that.' He goes even to destruction along with these beings. I do not see here any enjoyer other than myself. Thus it is said.

analyzed: nyāni lokāḥ kāmāḥ ca sarve mattaḥ nye ham eṣām svāmī iti
translated: That is accepted by Indra, by which knowledge he knows the beings and the Self, and does not know anything unpleasant. He obtains all the worlds and all the desires. This is indeed accepted by Indra. These beings are different from me, and all the worlds and desires are different from me. I am their lord.

analyzed: na tu etat indrasya hitam
translated: But this is not beneficial for Indra.

analyzed: hitam ca indrasya prajāpatinā vaktavyam
translated: And Prajapati should speak what is beneficial for Indra.

original: vyomavadaśarīrātmatayā sarvabhūtalokakāmātmatvopagamena yā prāptistaddhitamindrāya vaktavyamiti prajāpatinābhipretam /
analyzed: vyoma vat aśarīra ātmatayā sarva bhūta loka kāma ātmatva upagamena yā prāptiḥ tat hitam indrāya vaktavyam iti prajāpatinā abhipretam
translated: Prajāpati's intention is that Indra should be told that the attainment of the Self as all beings, worlds, and desires by realizing the Self as bodiless like the sky is beneficial.

analyzed: na tu rājñaḥ rājya āpti vat anya tvena
translated: But not as if the king were to attain a separate kingdom.

original: tatraivaṃ sati kaṃ kena vijānīyādātmaikatva imāni bhūtānyayamahamasmīti /
analyzed: tatra evam sati kam kena vijānīyāt ātma eka tve imāni bhūtāni ayam aham asmi iti
translated: In that case, how could one know any of these beings, thinking I am this?

original: nanvasminpakṣestrībhirvā yānairvā sa yadi pitṛlokakāmaḥ sa ekadhā bhavatiityādyaiśvaryaśrutayo 'nupapannāḥ / na /
analyzed: nanu asmin pakṣe strībhiḥ vā yānaiḥ vā sa yadi pitṛ loka kāmaḥ saḥ ekadhā bhavati ityādi aiśvarya śrutayaḥ nu papannāḥ na
translated: But in this view, the statements about lordship such as If he desires the world of the fathers, he becomes one-footed are not possible. No.

analyzed: sarva ātmanaḥ sarva phala saṃbandha upapatteḥ avirodhāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction in the possibility of the connection of all fruits with the Self of all.

analyzed: mṛdaḥ iva sarva gha ca karaka kuṇḍa ādi āptiḥ
translated: Like the attainment of all pots, pans, and bowls by clay.

analyzed: nanu sarva ātma tve duḥkha saṃbandhaḥ syāt iti ced na
translated: But if it is the Self of all, there would be the connection with suffering too, one may object. No.

analyzed: duḥkhasya api ātma tva upagamāt avirodhaḥ
translated: There is no contradiction because suffering is also accepted as the Self.

analyzed: ātmani avidyā kalpanā nimittāni duḥkhāni rajjvām iva sarpa ādi kalpanā nimittāni
translated: Sufferings, the basis for the conception of ignorance in the Self, are like the basis for the conception of a snake in a rope.

analyzed: sācā avidyā śarīra ātma ekatva svarūpa darśanena duḥkha nimitta ucchinnā ini duḥkha saṃbandha āśaṅkā na saṃbhavati
translated: And when the cause of suffering is cut off by the vision of the nature of the Self as the unity of the body of ignorance, the doubt of the connection with suffering does not arise.

analyzed: śuddha sattva saṃkalpa nimittānām tu kāmānām īśvara deha saṃbandhaḥ sarva bhūteṣu mānasānām
translated: But the desires caused by the will of pure beings are connected with the body of the Lord in all beings.

original: para eva sarvasattvopādhidvāreṇa bhokteti sarvāvidyākṛtasaṃvyavahārāṇāṃ para evā'tmā'spadaṃ
analyzed: paraḥ eva sarva sattva upādhi dvāreṇa bhoktā iti sarva avidyā kṛta saṃvyavahārāṇām paraḥ eva ātma āspadam
translated: The supreme Self alone is the enjoyer through the limiting adjuncts of all beings. Thus the supreme Self alone is the basis of all transactions created by ignorance.

analyzed: na anyaḥ sti iti vedānta siddhāntaḥ
translated: There is no other. This is the conclusion of the Vedanta.

original: ya eṣo 'kṣiṇi puruṣo dṛśyati iti cchāyāpuruṣa eva prajāpatinoktaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ eṣa u kṣiṇi puruṣaḥ dṛśyati iti chāyā puruṣaḥ eva prajāpatinā uktaḥ
translated: And in The person who is seen in the eye, Prajapati has spoken of the shadow-person alone.

analyzed: svapna suṣuptayoḥ ca anyaḥ eva
translated: And in dreams and deep sleep, there is another.

analyzed: na paraḥ upahata pāpma tva ādi lakṣaṇaḥ virodhāt iti kecid manyante
translated: Some think that the supreme one, characterized by being free from sin, etc., is not so, due to contradiction.

analyzed: chāyā ādi ātmanām ca upadeśe prayojanam ācakṣate
translated: And they explain the purpose of teaching the shadow-self, etc.

original: ādāvevocyamāne kila durvijñeyatvātparasyā'tmano 'tyantabāhyaviṣayāsaktacetaso 'tyantasūkṣmavastuśravaṇe vyāmoho mā bhūditi /
analyzed: ādau eva ucyamāne kila durvijñeya tvāt parasya ātmanaḥ tyanta bāhya viṣaya āsakta cetasaḥ tyanta sūkṣma vastu śravaṇe vyāmohaḥ mā bhūt iti
translated: When it is spoken of at the beginning, they say, due to the difficulty of knowing the supreme Self, let there be no delusion in the mind of one attached to external objects when hearing about the extremely subtle reality.

original: yathā kila dvitīyāyāṃ sūkṣmaṃ candraṃ didarśayiṣurvṛkṣaṃ kañcitpratyakṣamādau darśayati paśyāmumeṣa candra iti /
analyzed: yathā kila dvitīyāyām sūkṣmam candram didarśayiṣuḥ vṛkṣam kañcid pratyakṣam ādau darśayati paśya amum eṣa candraḥ iti
translated: Just as, for example, one wishing to show the subtle moon in the second month first shows a visible tree, saying Look at this, it is the moon.

original: tato 'nyaṃ tato 'pyanyaṃ girimūrdhānaṃ ca candrasamīpasthaṃ eṣa candra iti tato 'sau candraṃ paśyati /
analyzed: tatas tatas pi anyam girimūrdhānam ca candra samīpa stham eṣa candraḥ iti tatas sau candram paśyati
translated: Then another, and then another, and the peak of the mountain near the moon, thinking This is the moon, then he sees the moon.

original: evametadya eṣo 'kṣiṇītyādyuktaṃ prajāpatinā tribhiḥ paryāyairna para iti /
analyzed: evam etat yaḥ eṣa u kṣiṇi ityādi uktam prajāpatinā tribhiḥ paryāyaiḥ na paras iti
translated: Thus it is said by Prajapati in three stages beginning with He who is in the eye that the supreme is not.

analyzed: caturthe tu paryāye dehāt martyāt samutthāya aśarīra tām āpannaḥ jyotiḥ svarūpam
translated: But in the fourth stage, having risen from the mortal body and attained the state of being bodiless, he is of the nature of light.

original: yasminnuttamapuruṣe stryādibhirjakṣatkrīḍanramamāṇo bhavati sa uttmaḥ puruṣaḥ para ukta iti cā'huḥ /
analyzed: yasmin uttama puruṣe strī ādibhiḥ jakṣat krīḍan ramamāṇaḥ bhavati saḥ uttmaḥ puruṣaḥ paraḥ uktaḥ iti ca āhuḥ
translated: In whom the highest person, eating, playing, and delighting with women and others, that is the highest person, the supreme one, they say.

analyzed: satyam ramaṇīyā tāvat iyam vyākhyā śrotum
translated: True, this explanation is indeed pleasant to hear.

analyzed: na tu arthaḥ sya granthasya evam saṃbhavati
translated: But the meaning of this text is not possible in this way.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: akṣiṇi puruṣo dṛśyata ityupanyasya śiṣyābhyāṃ chāyātmani gṛhīte tayostadviparītagrahaṇaṃ
analyzed: akṣiṇi puruṣaḥ dṛśyate iti upanyasya śiṣyābhyām chāyā ātmani gṛhīte tayoḥ tad viparīta grahaṇam
translated: Having presented The person is seen in the eye, when the two disciples grasped the shadow-self, considering their contrary grasping,

original: matvā tadapanayāyodaśarāvopanyāsaḥ kiṃ paśyatha iti ca praśnaḥ sādhvalaṅkāropadeśaścānarthakaḥ
analyzed: matvā tad apanayāya uda śarāva upanyāsaḥ kim paśyatha iti ca praśnaḥ sādhu alaṅkāra upadeśaḥ ca anarthakaḥ
translated: for the removal of that, the presentation of the ten-platter and the question What do you see and the teaching of good ornaments would be meaningless

original: syāt yadi cchāyātmaiva prajāpatinākṣiṇi dṛśyata ityupadiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: syāt yadi chāyā ātmā eva prajāpatinā akṣiṇi dṛśyate iti upadiṣṭaḥ
translated: if the shadow-self alone were taught by Prajapati as The person is seen in the eye.

original: kiñca yadi svayamupadiṣṭa iti grahaṇasyāpyapanayakāraṇaṃ vaktavyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: kiñca yadi svayam upadiṣṭaḥ iti grahaṇasya api apanaya kāraṇam vaktavyam syāt
translated: Moreover, if the Self were taught by itself, then the reason for the removal of the apprehension of the Self would have to be stated.

original: svapnasuṣuptātmagrahaṇayorapi tadapanayakāraṇaṃ ca svayaṃ brūyāt na coktaṃtenaṭatena manyāmahe nākṣiṇi cchāyātmā prajāpatinopadiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: svapna suṣupta ātma grahaṇayoḥ api tad apanaya kāraṇam ca svayam brūyāt na ca uktam tena ṭatena manyāmahe na akṣiṇi chāyā ātmā prajāpatinā upadiṣṭaḥ
translated: He would himself state the reason for the removal of the apprehension of the Self in the states of dream and deep sleep, but he has not stated it. Therefore, we think that the Self of the shadow in the eye was not taught by Prajāpati.

original: kiṃ cānyadakṣiṇi draṣṭā ceddṛśyata ityupadiṣṭaḥ syāttata idaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: kim ca anya dakṣiṇi draṣṭā ced dṛśyate iti upadiṣṭaḥ syāt tatas idam yuktam
translated: Moreover, if the seer in the eye were taught as the seer, then this would be appropriate.

original: etaṃ tveva ta ityuktvā svapne 'pi draṣṭurevopadeśaḥ /
analyzed: etam tu eva te iti uktvā svapne draṣṭuḥ eva upadeśaḥ
translated: Having said This very Self of yours, the teaching is about the seer even in the dream state.

analyzed: svapne na draṣṭā upadiṣṭaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the seer is not taught in the dream state, that is not so.

analyzed: api roditi iva apriya vettā iva iti upadeśāt
translated: Because of the teaching He weeps as if knowing what is unpleasant.

analyzed: na ca draṣṭuḥ anyaḥ kaścid svapne mahīyamānaḥ carati
translated: And no one other than the seer moves about being honored in the dream state.

original: atrāyaṃ puruṣaḥ svayañjyotiriti nyāyataḥ śrutyantare siddhatvāt /
analyzed: atra ayam puruṣaḥ svayan jyotiḥ iti nyāyataḥ śruti antare siddha tvāt
translated: Here, this person is self-luminous, because it is established by reasoning in another scriptural passage.

original: yadyapi svapne sadhīrbhavati tathāpi na dhīḥ svapnabhogopalabdhiṃ prati karaṇatvaṃ bhajate /
analyzed: yadi api svapne sa dhīḥ bhavati tathā api na dhīḥ svapna bhoga upalabdhim prati karaṇa tvam bhajate
translated: Even though he has intellect in the dream state, still the intellect does not serve as an instrument for the perception of the enjoyment in the dream.

analyzed: tān niyamayan ātmani sva hṛdaye hārde brahmaṇi sarva indriyāṇi saṃpratiṣṭhāpya upasaṃhṛtya indriya grahaṇāt karmāṇi
translated: Restraining them in the Self, in the heart, in the internal Brahman, having withdrawn all the senses by withdrawing the senses,

analyzed: ca saṃnyasya ahiṃsa hiṃnsām para pīḍām akurvan sarva bhūtāni sthāvara jaṅgamāni bhūtāni apīḍayan iti arthaḥ
translated: and having renounced all actions, not injuring any beings, not causing pain to any beings, to all beings, both moving and unmoving. The meaning is: not causing pain to any beings.

analyzed: bhikṣā nimittam aṭana ādinā api para pīḍā syāt iti atas āha anyatra tīrthebhyaḥ
translated: There might be injury to others even by wandering for alms and so on, therefore he says: Except at sacred fords.

analyzed: tīrtham nāma śāsra anujñā viṣayaḥ tatas nyatra iti arthaḥ
translated: A sacred ford is the subject of scriptural permission. The meaning is: except at that.

analyzed: sarva āśramiṇām ca etat samānam tīrthebhyaḥ nyatra hiṃsā eva iti
translated: And this is common to all stages of life: except at sacred fords, there is injury.

original: anye varṇayanti kuṭumba evaitatsarvaṃ kurvansa khalvadhikṛto yāvadāyuṣaṃ yāvajjīvamevaṃyathoktena prakāreṇaiva vartayanbrahmalokamabhisaṃpadyatedehānte
analyzed: anye varṇayanti kuṭumbe eva etat sarvam kurvan sa khalu adhikṛtaḥ yāvadāyuṣam yāvajjīvam evam yathā uktena prakāreṇa eva vartayan brahma lokam abhisaṃpadyate dehānte
translated: Others describe it thus: One who performs all this while being a householder, he, being qualified, attains the world of Brahman at the end of the body,

analyzed: na ca punar āvartate śarīra grahaṇāya
translated: and does not return again to take up a body.

analyzed: punarāvṛtteḥ prāptāyāḥ pratiṣedhāt
translated: Because the prohibition of return, which is obtained, is stated.

original: arcirādinā mārgeṇa kāryabrahmalokabhisaṃpadya yāvadbrahmalokasthitistāvattatraiva tiṣṭhati prāktato nā'vartata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: arciḥ ādinā mārgeṇa kārya brahmaloka abhisaṃpadya yāvat brahmaloka sthitiḥ tāvat tatra eva tiṣṭhati prāk tatas na āvartate iti arthaḥ
translated: By the path beginning with light, he attains the world of Brahman, which is the effect, and as long as he remains in the world of Brahman, he remains there only, and does not return from there, is the meaning.

translated: The repetition twice is for the completion of the Upaniṣad knowledge.🔽Thus ends the fifteenth section in the eighth chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.
